citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An elderly female Hyena has a dark colored, pendulous, pear- shaped mass near the mammary area. The mass does not
appear to be injured or ulcerated, nor does it seem to cause the animal any discomfort. However, any physical change
such as this mass should be evaluated by a veterinarian to ensure the health of the animal. This mass was not observed
by the facility prior to inspection and therefore the animal has not been evaluated by a veterinarian to assess her health
and condition as related to the mass. Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being must be
provided. A mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on
problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. This Hyena must be
evaluated by a licensed veterinarian prior to the next scheduled re-license inspection.

The enclosure fence for the Giraffe has a broken top rail and is significantly leaning. The Giraffe was observed leaning
into and pushing the fence. The current fence is an ineffective enclosure barrier to the animal. Outdoor housing facilities
shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to contain and protect animals from injury. The facility must
repair or replace the fencing in order to safely contain and protect the giraffe.

In the drive- through area of the park there are several areas of the perimeter fence which are in need of repair.
-Near the entrance of site 002, a tree has fallen onto the perimeter fence. The fence is significantly lowered and in need of
repair.
-A section of perimeter fence behind the Tiger enclosure is damaged from a fallen tree and needs repair. Another section
of perimeter fence near the Tiger enclosure is also damaged from a fallen tree and in need of repair.
-A section of perimeter fence near the Safari Park drive through has been damaged, is significantly lowered, and in need
of repair.
-A section of fence near the Giraffe and Rhino enclosure is incomplete and has a gate less than eight feet in height.
-A section of perimeter fence near the Rhino enclosure has a gate less than eight feet in height and has a second gate
which has a deep washout of the soil directly underneath which creates a large opening.
The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and
unauthorized persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can
function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. Facilities housing potentially dangerous
animals must have a fence at least 8 feet in height. These requirements apply to all sections of the fence, including gates.

3.131(c)
The facility has a widespread issue with areas that are unclean and not in good repair.
-The Camel enclosure has a roll of old wire lying on the ground in the middle of the pasture. The wire has numerous sharp
points and is also an entrapment hazard.
-The pasture portion of the park near the Rhino exhibit has discarded wire, a broken gate, a section of exposed pipe, and
exposed electrical wiring that are potential sources of entrapment or injury to the Bison, Donkeys, and species of Sheep in
that area.
-The medical barn area has an enclosure for Jacob Sheep and Llamas that has a broken piece of board with nails
exposed to the animals.
-The medical barn area has an enclosure for Nilgai that has a long wire attached to an electrical pole. The suspended
wire is a potential source of injury to the enclosed animals.
Buildings and grounds shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to facilitate the
prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated areas and
cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 3, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An elderly female Hyena has a dark colored, pendulous, pear- shaped mass near the mammary area. The mass does not

3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The enclosure fence for the Giraffe has a broken top rail and is significantly leaning. The Giraffe was observed leaning

3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
In the drive- through area of the park there are several areas of the perimeter fence which are in need of repair.  
-Near the entrance of site 002, a tree has fallen onto the perimeter fence. The fence is significantly lowered and in need of

-A section of fence near the Giraffe and Rhino enclosure is incomplete and has a gate less than eight feet in height.  
-A section of perimeter fence near the Rhino enclosure has a gate less than eight feet in height and has a second gate

The perimeter fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and

function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. Facilities housing potentially dangerous 
animals must have a fence at least 8 feet in height. These requirements apply to all sections of the fence, including gates. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
3.131(c) 
The facility has a widespread issue with areas that are unclean and not in good repair. 
-The Camel enclosure has a roll of old wire lying on the ground in the middle of the pasture. The wire has numerous sharp 
points and is also an entrapment hazard.  
-The pasture portion of the park near the Rhino exhibit has discarded wire, a broken gate, a section of exposed pipe, and

-The medical barn area has an enclosure for Jacob Sheep and Llamas that has a broken piece of board with nails

-The medical barn area has an enclosure for Nilgai that has a long wire attached to an electrical pole. The suspended 
wire is a potential source of injury to the enclosed animals.  
 
Buildings and grounds shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury and to facilitate the 
prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in designated areas and

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the

All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 3, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license

Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: GRAY WOLF / GREY WOLF / TIMBER WOLF
